Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without a homomorphic crypto signing method that is supported by the blockchain, it is hard for me to see a way to do a decentralized 2FA. most likely these other systems use some sort of multisig with a centrally controlled (or decrypted) privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem is that if it is on the blockchain, it is on the blockchain and so everybody can extract the privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it isnt on the blockchain, then it requires trusing whomever to produce the key (or signature)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just because someone uses the words "decentralized 2FA" to describe something, it doesnt mean that it is actually a decentralized 2FA

Author: wl#4107
Content:
When we introduce the desired amount to swap, the input of the asset we are trading for should be auto filled with the the amount based on the latest value. That way we know if the orders available are fair...

Right now I have to access coinmarketcap or another and see how much is kmd (for ex) and how much is rvn (for ex) and do the math to know if the orders in the book are fair or to set my own order...

Author: wl#4107
Content: That makes a hugeee difference in my humble opinion...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
```Penalties
The primary penalty for breaches of conduct is a ban, which includes loss of trading privileges, forfeiture of registration fee, and immediate revocation of any unfilled orders.

Less drastic punitive measures such as a cool-down period may be considered for minor, first-time or infrequent conduct violations.```

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: seems totally unenforceable to random pubkeys on the internet

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: It's probably just legal mumbo jumbo

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: They probably make you register and whitelist pubkeys

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: Yeah that would be an option

Author: PTYX#6840
Content: I see that as viable for a regulated market like derivatives

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Yes,  this is why I suggested this functionality awhile back.  If the idea is to get exchanges and professionals involved they need to know who they are trading with  for compliance purposes.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: who manages the registration and blacklisting?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i would imagine they become subject to the regulations. maybe somebody wants to setup the registered DEX and make a special mm2 that uses the centralized DB of valid pubkeys. personally, i have no interest in such things, but i do understand maybe this is something that some people would want. nothing prevents this from being done, but it would take mm2 changes to automate the blacklisting

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @jl777c  if a DEX were to create a modified mm2 would it still be sharing liquidity with the original DEX or is it its own system at that point?

Author: gcharang#6833
Content: if the only parts changed are related to whitelisting pubkeys, then liquidity will be reduced to only those pubkeys

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: depends on the details of the blacklisting.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it is a blacklisting only, then most of the liquidity would be shared, but if it requires whitelisting to trade at all, it would create a separate liquidity pool

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: of course, if there was just a single whiteliested pubkey that ran something similar to the CEX liquidity bridge, this would effectively pool the two liquidity together
